C is my choice

choices.D: Utilize SDDC Manager to upgrade NSX-T to the latest version.
choices.C: Use VMware Lifecycle Manager to upgrade NSX-T to the latest version.
choices.A: Upgrade VMware Cloud Foundation to a version that includes this patch.
choices.B: Apply the latest HotFix directly to NSX-T to address the issue immediately.

questions.question_text:
A bug has been identified in VMware NSX-T that causes ESXi hosts to randomly PSOD and crash when a high volume of firewall rules are being applied. VMware has released an update for NSX-T to address the issue.
Which method should the administrator use to apply this update to the environment?

choices.B: The administrator should login to the master controller to access all site data.
choices.C: Any node in the system will provide the information across all instances.
choices.A: VMware Cloud Foundation will federate, but access to all sites is only available in the vSphere client.
choices.D: The administrator should still log into each individual site.

questions.question_text:
An administrator has to work with multiple VMware Cloud Foundation sites, and Multi-Instance Federation is setup.
How can the administrator access different sites?

discussion.content:
answer should be C
Please read REF: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.3/vcf-admin/GUID-3DA5C89A-DA53-4EB4-91C6-AE39B212F0DC.html

Selected Answer: C
it´s in course materials

Selected Answer: C
C, it´s in course materials

Selected Answer: C
As mentioned by others, correct answer should be C.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.3/vcf-admin/GUID-3DA5C89A-DA53-4EB4-91C6-AE39B212F0DC.html
It’s C. Federation members can view inventory access across the VCF instances in the federation. They can also view the available and used capacity (CPU, memory and storage)
did you do the exam based on this dump?

Selected Answer: B
Since they have not mentioned HA, then administrator can only work through master controller.

comments.content:
HA is not required for federation to work.
Each member can view information about the entire federation and the individual instances within it, so answer C should be the correct one.

choices.E: Upgrade prechecks are optional to guarantee the success of the upgrade, but they can be skipped.
choices.D: Upgrade prechecks validate that all required bundles are downloaded successfully to the SDDC Manager.
choices.A: Upgrade prechecks validate that ESXi hosts have enough space on principal storage for the ISO image staging.
choices.B: Upgrade prechecks validate that custom ESXi ISOs are compatible with the current environment in VUM-based workload domains.
choices.C: Upgrade prechecks will not allow continuing the upgrade if there's one or more alarms.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct concerning the upgrade pre-checks of the VMware Cloud Foundation 4.x upgrade process? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
bundle precheck
- The custom ISO file is compatible with your enviroment
- The custom ISO file is smaller than boot partition size.
- The Third-party VIBs are compatible with the environment.
B and C are correct answers. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.4/vcf-lifecycle/GUID-E3F6EEFF-698F-48F0-BCBF-E6CAEF6C1EBD.html

Selected Answer: BD

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.4/vcf-lifecycle/GUID-409447A2-FF47-4B64-BAE8-1C00943CB6A8.html
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.4/vcf-lifecycle/GUID-E3F6EEFF-698F-48F0-BCBF-E6CAEF6C1EBD.html

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.
Procedure is described here : https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.2/com.vmware.vcf.vxrail.admin.doc/GUID-28DF03BC-654B-4E41-A3C1-230B356E87C6.html

Selected Answer: A
tricky question. 
we have 2 cases here:
+ If two of the three NSX-T Manager nodes in the NSX-T Manager cluster are in a failed state, you begin the restore process by deactivating the cluster.

If only one of the three NSX-T Manager nodes in the NSX-T Manager cluster is in a failed state, you directly restore the failed node to the cluster by deploy new node.
My choice would be A

choices.A: Disconnect VMware NSX Manager from VMware vCenter.
choices.D: Restart the existing VMware NSX Manager.
choices.C: Migrate the existing VMware NSX Manager.
choices.B: Deploy a new VMware NSX Manager into VMware vCenter.

questions.question_text:
There has been a service outage that has caused VMware NSX Manager to become unresponsive, and it must be recovered from the last known good backup. The backed up configuration file has been located, and the restore procedure is ready to commence.
Which step should be taken first?
